A note from Pocantico's Superintendent: Dear Parents,

Thank you for sharing your children with us!

It was so great to have the students back! Whether in the building or virtually, their presence is the reason and basis for our campus and the profession as a whole. At one point today I looked down the hallway and saw two students skipping,( in a socially distanced fashion of course) and I am quite sure that my smile was apparent even under my mask!

Drop-off and pick went well and I am sure that it will become even more streamlined and effective as we all learn and get back into our routines.

Please remember to encourage your children to employ safe practices while waiting at the bus stop; mask up and social distance as feasible.

Please visit our Transportation Page to view our new School Bus Safety Rules and Student Responsibilities. https://www.pocanticohills.org/transportation

Remember, we are all in this together and we are here to help!

Thank you all,

Rich

Happy New Year! Pocantico celebrated the Lunar New Year! To start the day, four students who speak Chinese did the morning announcements. During lunch, parent volunteers gave students fortune cookies and lucky red envelopes, plus an ancient Chinese coin that they could wear as a bracelet for good luck. In China, red envelopes are presented as gifts on special occasions and holidays. The color of the envelope, red, symbolizes good luck and wards off evil spirits.

Lunar new year is celebrated in many Asian countries such as China, Japan, Korea, Vietnam, and more.

Thank you to our parent volunteers!

Happy Lunar New Year to all!

The flu has officially hit Pocantico, and Nurse Gay wants all families to be healthy! Let's remind our kids about the importance of washing our hands with soap and water, including before we eat, whether at school, home, or elsewhere. If someone in your house is sick, you can use Lysol to sanitize objects.

Kids should stay home from school when sick in order to recover and to minimize the spread of sickness to fellow students, staff, and those who have high-risk family members such as infants, elderly, and those with compromised immune systems. Nurse Gay endorses this article which contains tips and suggestions.

As New Yorkers, we know that applying salt/ice melt is sometimes necessary to keep our roads and walkways safe. But how can we minimize its environmental impact, and what are the alternatives?

Kevin, our Facilities & Grounds Manager, is with us to talk us through some of what he looks for—and what he looks OUT for—when it comes to buying ice melt.
